Description: Egyptian terracotta female figure with curly hair worn down. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of white coating. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis terracottas workshop that was operational from the 3rd to the 2nd century BC, and possibly later. Parallel in the Louvre dated to the Roman period (Dunand 1990, no.351). '21' written on back in pencil; if this is a findspot indication rather than a catalogue number it might suggest this was from a level Gutch thought earlier than the Roman town. Dunand, F. 1990, Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte, Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.180) (Phase 1)
